name: qsv-diff
description: Find the difference between two CSVs with ludicrous speed! e.g. _compare two CSVs with 1M rows x 9 columns in under 600ms!_

options.description: Set ALL delimiters to this character. Overrides --delimiter-right, --delimiter-left and --delimiter-output.
The field delimiter for reading CSV data on the left. Must be a single character. (default: ,)
The field delimiter for writing the CSV diff result. Must be a single character. (default: ,)
The field delimiter for reading CSV data on the right. Must be a single character. (default: ,)
Drop values of equal fields in modified rows of the CSV diff result (and replace them with the empty string). Key field values will not be dropped.

The column indices that uniquely identify a record as a comma separated list of 0-based indices, e.g. 0,1,2 or column names, e.g. name,age. Note that when selecting columns by name, only the left CSV's headers are used to match the column names and it is assumed that the right CSV has the same selected column names in the same order as the left CSV. (default: 0)
When set, the first row will be considered as part of the left CSV to diff. (When not set, the first row is the header row and will be skipped during the diff. It will always appear in the output.)
When set, the diff result won't have a header row in its output. If not set and both CSVs have no headers, headers in the result will be: _col_1,_col_2, etc.
When set, the first row will be considered as part of the right CSV to diff. (When not set, the first row is the header row and will be skipped during the diff. It will always appear in the output.)
Write output to <file> instead of stdout.

The column indices by which the diff result should be sorted as a comma separated list of indices, e.g. 0,1,2 or column names, e.g. name,age. Records in the diff result that are marked as "modified" ("delete" and "add" records that have the same key, but have different content) will always be kept together in the sorted diff result and so won't be sorted independently from each other. Note that when selecting columns by name, only the left CSV's headers are used to match the column names and it is assumed that the right CSV has the same selected column names in the same order as the left CSV.

examples.description: Find the difference between two CSVs
Find the difference between two CSVs when the right CSV has no headers
Find the difference between two CSVs when the left CSV uses a tab delimiter
Find the difference between two CSVs when the left CSV uses a semicolon delimiter
Find the difference between two CSVs and write output with tab delimiter to a file
Find the difference between two CSVs and write output with semicolon delimiter to a file
Find the difference comparing records with the same values in the first two columns
Find the difference using first two columns as key and sort result by those columns
Find the difference but replace equal field values with empty string (key fields still appear)
Find the difference but do not output headers in the result
Find the difference when both CSVs have no headers (generic headers _col_1, _col_2, etc. are used)
